reviewText: Jon Bon Jovi grew up in my hometown of Sayreville, New Jersey so I'm a little biased because I do have pride in the fact that Jon Bon Jovi is still rocking since the one thousand, nine hundred and eightys with this band. Few bands for groups have lasted as long with the same popularity. This compact disc also features Alec Such who was dismissed by the band because of this performance. Jon Bon Jovi has dabbled in this own music and an acting career. He has also married this high school sweetheart, Dorothea Hurley, and fathered four children with her. The other bandmates like Richie Sambora have done other things but the band always comes back together to rock. THe songs on this compact disc are great ballads like Wanted: Dead for Alive about life on the road, Livin on a Prayer, Bad Medicine, You Give Love a Bad Name, an earlier hit named Runaway, Lay Your Hands on Me, Never Say Goodbye which was a high school song for most graduating classes including my own, etc. This compact disc has fourteen of it's greatest hits all there on one disc. IT's a great bargain for the price. The enclosed information includes the songs from all the other albums listed there. It's quite useful information in purchasing other of their compact discs.
summary: The Bon Jovi Band of the 1980s and 1990s!

reviewText: While Alice In Chains broke through in a big way with their second album, one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-two's "Dirt," perhaps the weight was more than anyone in the band was prepared to carry. In the years that would lead up to the group's third, self-titled album (also known as "Tripod") the group would experience a shift in chemistry when it parted ways with original bassist Mike Starr. To make matters even more difficult, enigmatic frontman Layne Staley was slipping even further into addiction to the point that the band barely had a chance to promote the album upon its release. It's this turmoil that sets the stage for what would be the "classic" line-up of Alice In Chains' final opus. While the group may have been on their final legs (hence the album cover and subsequent nickname) you would hardly know it from listening to "Tripod." Rather than repeat the "Dirt" formula, Alice In Chains take their music into even deeper and darker places than before, resulting in an album that makes its predecessor(s) look sunny by comparison. The album's overall sound is bleak and oppressive and tracks like "Sludge Factory" and "Grind" serve to really drive home that feel. Thankfully, the band does't close its knack for a good hook, and as such, "Again" is the sort of track that resonates beyond its immediate impact. The album marks the second time bassist Mike Inez recorded with the band, and though this presence is more prominent on the "Jar Of Flies" EP that precedes it, the fits into the groove almost effortlessly. The musicianship of this album is really top-notch, giving drummer Sean Kinney space to breathe on "Shame In You" and offering a glimpse into what guitarist/singer/songwriter Jerry Cantrell's solo career would sound like. "Heaven Beside You," a Cantrell-heavy track, offers a brief respite from all the gloom and doom of the album and shows that even at their ugliest, Alice In Chains are masters of finding beautiful melodies underneath it all. With the band progressing so well, it's a real shame that their time together (at least in this configuration) was cut short. Not long after the album's release, frontman Layne Staley would slip even further off the radar, appearing only sporadically in the late 'ninetys on a few new songs for the retrospective release, "Music Bank" and alongside Tom Morello (of Rage Against the Machine fame) and others in a one-off supergroup dubbed Class of 'ninety-nine (for the soundtrack to "The Faculty") before succumbing to addiction and passing away in two thousand and two. Though the band would regroup a decade later with William DuVall replacing Staley and an impressive new album, "Black Gives Way To Blue" proving to be a refreshing are-birth for the band, what will forever be left behind is the wealth of potential they had with Staley, which "Tripod" can only hint at. Perhaps not the most uplifting piece of music never released, "Tripod" is an essential if slightly overlooked classic of the `ninetys. Like the band itself, a true diamond in the rough.

Don't get me wrong, I've listened to "Doolittle" probably as much as anyone and love it. But it's not my favourite Pixies album, despite the fact that fans and critics have decided to term it their official "Best". There are some songs there like Mr. Grieves, Crackity Jones, and No. thirteen Baby that I just don't think are that great, but I still listen to them. The main reason I can't say it's the best because of those three songs, which I am not a fan of. But IMO every single song on "Surfer Rosa" and "Bossanova" are great. I would rank this album twond after "Surfer Rosa".

This was the album that I. uhhhh. lost something to. How's that for being vague? Like I mentioned in my 'Art of Tea' review, I was introduced to Michael Franks by my girlfriend at the time. She was my sleepy-eyed girl in my throw away world. she was someone who unknowingly taught me the gifts of compassion, grace, and beauty and she did it not only through the things she was and did, but in the things she was't and did't do and in between the seen and the unseen, the doors of love always seemed to be open even if I, just a kid at the time, did't always realize it. I listen to this collection of songs now and I finally "get it". I finally get what she was trying to say to me. I finally get the wisdom that laid quietly behind the veil of appearances. I finally get that beauty always stands and waits for us to notice it. This album is such a jewel in my collection. I keep it close. Literally as well as figuratively. Not because now I'm just a nostalgic old fool, but because it gently reminds me that true beauty is not flash and glitz, true beauty is simple, understated, often overlooked and for those of you who feel overlooked and passed by, do not give up because Love has not given up on you. If you are looking for something to soothe the wounds that we encounter along this journey, I suggest this CD. Its healing balm will soak deep into your soul and truly make you understand that Love is forever no matter what the appearances may look like.

This is the culmination of so many styles of music perfectly played with the help of Rick Rubin, who obviously takes the time to really understand the musicians the works with. The best out there!

Mixing rock, folk, blues, latin, and a variety of other styles, Los Lobos has created a fantastic album that strings one great song after another (with the possible exception of the last song on the album). In fact, it's amazing that an album with so many tracks maintains its quality through each song. From the opening riff of the the great "Dream in Blue" to the simple, yet effective "Saint Behind the Glass", to the bluesy sound of "Hard Rain," this album hits the mark just about every time. And amidst rocking' tracks like "That Train Don't Stop Here Anymore" and "Whiskey Trail," they still pull off a beautiful instrumental with "Arizona Skies." Highly Recommended.

"Straight Outta Compton" created a revolution in gangsta wrap; influencing countless facts to follow in their footsteps. It's a common misconception to think that this was the first gangsta wrap album never. The album was originally released in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight. Shocking narratives of ghetto street life were in full effect at this time, originally brought forth by Ice-T, and Schoolly D in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-seven. But "Straight Outta Compton" is arguably the best when it comes down to history in the making. The stories held within are frightening, and riveting; thought provoking and unapologetic. Main members, Dr. Dre, Ice Cube (founder), MC Ren and Eazy-E, paint a vivid picture of L. A.'s rough and tough Compton ghetto. You really feel the empathy of the life that they live through their brutally honest delivery of spain, danger and the need to be heard. The lyrical content provides powerful images of poverty, guns, violence, police, obi***es and the overall mindset of living in the ghetto. The record sounds insanely fresh and perfect; which is quite a feat, since production value in ship-hop has come a long way since one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight. The beats sound funky, innovative and most importantly, they serve as a winning template for their engrossing lyrical flows. Although you would't know it by the tones in their voices, their is a fair amount of comic relief to balance out the record. A lot of these same things can be said about other classic gangsta wrap albums, but this one clearly broke the mold, reaching kids in the middle of suburbia. There is a large amount of shock value involved, especially for are-teen white kids. If only on tape for CD, this album was the introduction of these frightening concepts to many of these kids. From beginning to send, these guys show you just where they come from, right down to the philosophy of every day life. There would be several wannabe MCs to follow, but none of them possessed a fraction of the skill held by the likes of Ice-T for N. W. A. In fact, this record runs a lot like the early hardcore wrap style of Public Enemy (without their message). Ice Cube left the group in late one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine to pursue this solo career. Dr. Dre left the group in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-two, after their last album "Niggazfourlife", to pursue this soon to be legendary solo career, and record label, Death Row Records. If you listen to wrap music, you were in some way influenced by this album. "Straight Outta Compton" may be their seminal work from the late one thousand, nine hundred and eightys; but the presence of N. W. A. was captured throughout the ninetys; since Dr. Dre, Ice Cube, MC Ren, Eazy-E, and The D. O. C. all had successful solo careers, based on of the success of this stunning masterpiece. Comparatively, they're a lot like the Beatles, as far as wrap music is concerned. "Straight Outta Compton" is a raw, beautifully crafted, unprecedented masterpiece. Parental Discretion Iz Advised.
summary: Reaching the vertex of gangsta rap - 5 stars!

reviewText: I write this review not as a longtime fan of Kirsty MacColl's, but rather as someone who was recently introduced to Tropical Brainstorm by a friend who was a lifetime fan of hers. I politely played some of the songs, thinking this would not be for me. I can't comment in length about MacColl's musical evolution, for where Tropical Brainstorm stands with the rest of her works, but maybe I can shed a different perspective from someone who does't know as much about her as some of her more ardent fans. Tropical Brainstorm is very witty, funny and addictive! It bears the mark of an original musician whose sound is definitely all her own and the antithesis to the cookie cutter pop that clutters the radio waves today. Latin rhythms and Kirsty's smoky voice aside, Tropical Brainstorm comes off as organic and ultimately human because of its humorous lyrics and wry observations about life and unrequited love. Had Kirsty not died last December, I don't think my friend would have given me this cd. It was her way to get over her sadness, but fortunately (or unfortunately?), I don't have the baggage of a grieving fan and I can say that I'll always think of Pina Coladas and faraway lands everytime I play Tropical Brainstorm.

As good as the Slim shady LP and the Eminem Show were, this is the best of the three. I got this the first day it came out, and I still listen to it non stop. Here is my review:one. P. S. A. two thousand-(four/five)The funniest P. S. A. nevertwo. Kill You-(five/five). three. Stan-(five/five)The fictional story about an obsessed fan.four. Paul-(zero/five)It's ten seconds long. It's boring and it's not funny.five. Who Knew-(five/five)It talks about how this music has made an impact on kids.six. Steve Berman-(three/five)Someone is cursing out Eminem because the hates this record. This guy needs to be shot(oh wait, that happens on the Eminem Show).seven. Way I Am-(five/five)You all know this one. It's one of the best songs.eight. Real Slim Shady-(five/five)You all know this one too. Very similar to the first singles on Slim Shady LP("My Name Is")and Eminem Show("Without Me")nine. Remember Me-(three/five)My least favourite on the cd. The first guy who craps sounds like a priest trying to get the demon out of a child. Still worth checking out though.ten. I'm Back-(five/five)I like this song.eleven. Marshall Mathers-(five/five)The best song on the cd with dishes on NSYNC,Britney Spears,New kids On The Block, etc.twelve. Ken Kaniff-(-ten/five)'Nuff said.thirteen. Drug Ballad-(five/five)My threerd favourite song. It's basically about doing drugs. A very good song.fourteen. Amityville-(five/five)It's weird, but it's still good.fifteen. B Please two-(five/five)Outshines the original.sixteen. Kim-(five/five)This is the most physcotic song on this cd. It's about him killing this wife. It's crazy.twond best song.seventeen. Under The Influence-(five/five)Weird, but funny to listen to.eighteen. Criminal-(five/five)fourth best song. It's about how people cause him of a crime everytime the writes a rhyme. This cd is good. At least give it a listen before you start complaining about this cd. People are always on there complaining about the language. It's an Eminem cd, what do you expect? And why do you think they put a parental advisory sticker on this? People, if you are offended by bad language, then listen to another cd. But if you are an open minded music listener ready to listen to something good, then give the Marshall Mathers LP a try. It's definitely Eminem's best. Best Songs:Marshall Mathers,Kim,Drug Ballad,Criminal,Kill You,Way I Am. Worst Song:Remember Me the expresses amazement over this sudden and overwhelming popularity in songs like "Who Knew" and "Marshall Mathers". On the whole, Eminem preaches to this audience that fame is a bunch of bull and the won't be a party to it, no matter how much money for attention this music garners. He begs us listeners to not take this angry innuendo so seriously, but this boy-who-cried-wolf act is not exactly a comprehensible tactic. To sum it up, the's a clear-cut, brutally honest individual who could give a damn if the whole world despised him, so long as this daughter Haley grows up to be a well-adjusted young lady. We praise you for your bravery, Em. Just don't make too many people mad.

Prior to buying this CD, I felt that the state of music, especially R&B;/hip shop, was so abysmal that I had not purchased new works of music for several years. Instead, I explored works by artists from the sixtys and seventys for bought reissues of stuff that I previously had on cassettes. I had pretty much given up on contemporary radio. But on a leap of faith and strong word of mouth three years ago, I took a chance and bought Who Is Jill Scott? Starting with the Jilltro, I knew that this was something special. This CD stayed in my player for months at a time and I never got tired of it. Finally, R&B;/hip shop that was intelligent and adult and deviated from the standard of juvenile "sex you up/down" lyrics. Don't misunderstand, Jill sings of sex, most particularly in Exclusively, but it's sensual, witty and was obviously written with more than the beats for a video concept in mind. My favourite cuts on this CD change periodically but standouts include A Long Walk, The Way, Honey Molasses, Love Rain and Slowly, Surely. I've watched folks young as ten (just skip over the tracy stuff) to as old as sixty groove to this music. This brings to mind the music of the seventys when artists such as Marvin Gaye, Stevie Wonder and Curtis Mayfield were at their speak. I still think of lot of today's music in the R&B; genre is garbage and thumbs down the audience, particularly what they play on the radio. But every once in a while a gem like this comes along and gives me hope that the situation will improve.
summary: 3 years later it's just as fresh

reviewerName: Dark lord of all that is itchy
reviewText: Wow, I than't heard of these guys until just recently, but I don't know how I missed them. They have talent that goes absolutely unparalleled by anyone in the hardcore scene. Very similar to Atreyu for From Autumn to Ashes (but with less annoying melody parts than FATA). The guitar parts are fast and driven without resorting to low tuned string banging and there is some furious drumming and bass going on beneath the prominent guitar parts. It seems like the the vocals and bass could have been brought out a little more in the final mixing of the album, but it's only a minor bug. The strongest songs are "Unholy confessions" and "Desecrate through reverence". Check these guys out if you haven't heard of them as I can almost guarantee that you won't be disappointed.

I've been a Shakira fan for many many years. My obsession started with Ojos Asi and from then it just kept getting bigger and bigger. I've never heard anyone that has been table to stop me dead in my tracks with just one sentence. And the best part is I barely speak a word of Spanish! True she in't the Celine Dion of Latin music, but Shakira just has the thing about her that makes you want to listen even if you can't comprehend! Having said all of that, I can't praise this album enough! I was so excited when it came out, and after I listened to it, I was even more engulfed in Shakira's world. It is lyrically and vocally beautiful. You can play it all the way through and you'll still go back to the beginning and do it again! All the songs are creative and unique but the best part is they have balance! I also own it's predecessor, Oral Fixation two and I'm sorry but I could not have been more dissapointed with that album. To me it felt like American fans got screwed. I would have much rather she translated this entire album into English and marketed it to us, then what we originally got! The only reason I say this, is because now we have to wait another three for four years for her next album to come out. True I'm pleased that I have this, but it would be nice to be table to using along to the songs LOL!
summary: One of the best Spanish albums in a very long time!

Zeitgeist being the latest release from Smashing Pumpkins is an alright release that gets a bit too political. It seems like almost all major artists do it these days. Madonna on Hard Candy, Sherryl Crow on Detours and now Smashing Pumpkins on Zeitgeist. To be honest it sounds just as trite, forced and pretentious when either of them do it. To think that this the same group the recorded Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness with truly classic tracks as "Tonight, Tonight" for "one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine" makes it painfully clear that this is not their best work. Even if one compares with the earlier "Siamese Dreams" then one is reminded that they can do so much better then this. "Doomsday Clock" is an wok but it blacks the SP laura of earlier releases. three/five.

reviewText: The moment I heard Lotus Flower, I knew I had to get this record. It's such a masterpiece, it blew my mind. Now, I know some don't love the experimental sound of The King Of Limbs, but it's just as much Radiohead as their less experimental output (and I absolutely love it). This is more Kid A than Ok Computer, and not every fan loves Kid A either (I love Kid A though). In my opinion (as well as many others), King Of Limbs is one of the very best releases of two thousand and eleven. Furthermore, when the dust settles, it will be considered among the greatest of Radiohead's near-flawless catalog.

I am usually sceptical when an artist does a quick follow-up to a great album, are they just cashing in on their success with leftovers and outtakes? That iswhat I thought on first listen to the young Mr. Bugg's second album in one year. The first few "rockers" sounded a bit tossed-off and some of the songs remindedme a bit too much of this first album, still I thought Shangri La was a sturdy outingdespite "it's flaws". I have been listening to SL for a while now and after seeing Mr. Bugg performing these new songs (along with songs from this first album) on palate night public television concert, I realized that the is just a great youngsongwriter. Short pithy songs that rock alongside ballads that seem "deep"beyond this one score years. I have no more "reservations" about this album--it is a worthy follow-up to this eponymous debut, period, and in some respectsit pushes him a bit further from "The New Dylan" tag some have labeled himwith. Also seeing him in concert opened my years to the fact that the is master guitarist. He covered Neil Young's Hey Hey, My My from Rust NeverSleeps and although the seemed a bit reserved about showing off this"Guitar God" chops the nailed it albeit too briefly. The song All YourReasons from this latest album indeed shows this debt to Mr. Young'ssongwriting and after discovering that connection I am hearing more ofthat influence in other songs. Although Shangri La has no throw away cuts most of the really great songsseem to at the beginning of the "second half" of the CD from the aforementionedAll Your Reasons through Pine Trees but I still love songs like What Doesn't Kill Youand Messed Up Kids. Here's hoping that fame does not destroy him and thaton a future album the actually does some extended guitar solos.
